subtasks: Test forages and co-products for nitrate accumulation
Sample feeds for nutrient analysis
Adjust rations based on feed nitrogen levels and energy content
Balance rations with appropriate levels of protein, energy, and minerals for desired average daily gain (ADG)
Consider local feed sources and transportation costs when formulating rations
Utilize co-products such as wheat middlings, distillers grains, and corn gluten feed to enhance protein and fiber content
Evaluate the use of energy sources like corn grain, corn silage, and alfalfa hay in rations
Account for water quality and availability in feeding management
Monitor management practices for feeding efficacy and disease prevention (e.g., ionophores, implants, dequinate, corred for coccidiosis control)
Assess the trade-off between energy (corn) and protein (co-products) in rations
Calculate the cost per pound of gain and adjust rations to optimize cost efficiency
Leverage higher gain rations (e.g., 3.4 pounds ADG) despite higher feed costs for improved overall profitability
Test feeds for moisture content and adjust for high-water content due to drought (e.g., corn silage)
Balance high-energy feeds with appropriate protein sources to mitigate the risk of death loss associated with high nitrate levels
Identify and manage variability in feed quality due to drought conditions and local forage availability
Formulate rations incorporating supplements like distillers grains or corn grain to support higher ADG goals
Assess and adjust calcium and phosphorus levels when incorporating high-phosphorus feeds like distillers grains
Evaluate the impact of protein levels on energy requirements and cost
Contract for feed supply to ensure availability during peak demands
Seek USDA programs for feed transportation assistance
Consider geographic feed options to balance cost and supply with available sources within North Dakota
